1107548949768884225.text: I’ve been doing a kind of ongoing series of personal drawings where I’m basically trying to be as uninhibited about exploring architectural form as possible, and I’ve been debating about when & how to share them for a while.

1101152899579539457.text: Using Uber always halfway made you wonder if the software was buggy or broken, & it’s interesting how much of a difference more responsive graphics make just from a first impression. 1101152268080959489.text: As a result of having a bad experience with Uber I recently decided to install the Lyft app. I haven’t used the service yet, but just from messing around with their interface it’s interesting how much more responsive and intuitive its menus etc. feel to use.

1099378912327389185.text: The initial project was abbreviated due to school deadlines, but I came up with some preliminary observations.

1099377988020269056.text: A common theme could be how devices with curved plastic enclosures represented a new era of design enabled by computer 3D modeling technologies, so it felt like there was a kind of symmetry to feeding images of them back into a digital system.

1099377616946049024.text: Some examples of the kinds of images I was using as input... everything from different models of cell phones to digital cameras and CD/MP3 players to more mundane categories of devices such as home thermostat/fan control systems and (not shown) medical devices and car key fobs.pic.twitter.com/ekLHCkOmRs

1099377172865634304.text: Experimented last year with running images of late 90s/early 2000s portable electronic devices through a GAN machine learning algorithm, to see what new configurations of devices it would produce.pic.twitter.com/3mDcXYRfiQ

1099328361963282433.text: If these concerns are valid then that also creates a problem where one of the main reasons I became interested in that interdisciplinary intersection in the first place was because I knew that I faced obstacles to more conventional paths of advancement within architecture itself.

1099317774214545408.text: Also, the suggestion of “finding better people” is hard for me to understand as a potential type of advice when it’s also the initial motive behind my goal of trying to become more relevant & interesting in the first place.

1099316870983835648.text: From my perhaps distorted perspective I’m concerned that at least a relatively prominent part of the tech world doesn’t have a framework for imagining how to be sympathetic to considering those views (even in the sense of “I’m going to entertain this POV I disagree with”) at all.

1099316452220227586.text: More specifically, I’m less concerned about different views of economic policies being a dealbreaker than the extent to which my understanding of design and architecture has been intertwined (for a long time) with a belief in postmodernism.

1099314942300155911.text: I keep hoping some kind of productive outcome will happen from my interest in exploring intersections btwn the built environment & technology, but I wonder if theres a limit to how far I’ll be able to advance on my current path because I have the wrong political & cultural views.

1093087911442956289.text: You correspondingly could change the hierarchy of logistics which currently goes with small numbers of drivers/large vehicles, ie transporting objects between regional warehouses before reaching their local destinations instead of going straight from any point to the destination.

1093087620161105920.text: You could have a swarm of small vehicles immediately transporting individual/small numbers of objects to their destinations as soon as they were ready be shipped, instead of waiting to more fully load a larger vehicle.

1093087403558895616.text: Brand new insight I just had about automated vehicles which I'm not immediately sure what to do with: we wouldn't need large freight vehicles as much as we do now if the vehicle didn't need to be sized according to the economies of scale of minimizing the need for drivers.

1089635699949592576.text: - in NY I felt like it was generally easier to wear whatever I wanted to without sticking out and attracting uncomfortable forms of attention.

1089634213349838848.text: - I felt like there was easier access to a wider range of healthy food where I was in NY. It almost seems like salads (ex. that you could conveniently get from somewhere as take-out after a busy day) aren’t really a thing in the Bay Area.

1089633553304834048.text: - I would spend a lot more time walking around outside just for its own sake in NY. (Including in the winter.) Probably due to a combination of being in a stimulating visual environment and the subway access making it easy to decide to walk for part of a journey.

1089632861492146176.text: - I could read on the NY subway without getting motion sickness, which isn’t the case with the BART. The last long-ish commute I had in NY was a lot more bearable because of that.

1089632451649986560.text:
Little differences which I’m thinking of:
- the comprehensiveness of the NY subway made it a lot easier to spontaneously travel to social or networking type events.

1089631617084080128.text: A part of me has been wishing in the back of my mind that I would move back to NY, but it’s mostly over a lot of differences in everyday life which each seem individually trivial on their own.

1089631013867728896.text: How many subtle quality of life differences does it take to justify living in one place vs. another?

1089457827058315264.text: (Ex. a simple example of how that works would be the advice they at least used to give in certain Ivy League arch schools of how you ideally need to make time for enough of a social life while you’re there to meet future clients. Ofc. that’s easier said than done for most people)

1089456920501444608.text: ...that situation can be just as toxic to your future self as it is to other people.

1089456861869334528.text: And then when the activity has a cult-like atmosphere surrounding it which perhaps gives you a little bit more of a sense of meaning and purpose, and even exceptionalism compared to the other people who aren’t working as hard & haven’t made it as far as you...

1089456068558610432.text: I also saw earlier signs it was something I was compelled by, but in general it’s too easy at college age (ex. for ppl whose lives have so far only involved school work) to assume taking the path of doing something that involves harder work will necessarily be rewarding in future

1089456067489148928.text: But I sometimes wonder a little bit if I became too enthusiastic about architecture too early on because of how much it was presented in college as something that seemed hard to do.

1089454758342025218.text: (A lot of my reason for saying that is due to things like external economic conditions, but that’s another story.)

I really have empathy for the architect I interned with back in high school where the 1st thing he said when I entered his office was “go become a dentist.” It’s not a field you should pursue unless you’re so compelled you have no choice, & in that case nothing will stop you.

1089453179547246592.text: Unpopular opinion: One overlooked problem with the competitive culture & hazing in some parts of architecture’s professional & academic spheres may be how it can encourage people to enter the field just because it seems hard.

1084244552339410944.text: This also applies to objects which are known for being energy-inefficient in operation, as well as to those subjected to recalls. Semi-related terms might apply to those produced under problematic conditions, or those associated with bad taste more generally.

1084243766121283584.text: There should be a term for the subtle social programming that teaches you some objects are bad to have in your home. ex. took me a while to realize a halogen lamp or a space heater is a reasonable thing to own after hearing during formative years about them being banned in dorms.

1084178478436622336.text: Theater/dance: valuable collectible artifacts of a past civilization which are no longer accepted anywhere as legal tender.

1084176602047700993.text: Virtual/augmented reality: like Bitcoin, it's backed by computer processing power and nobody knows what it can be used for. Bypasses borders between different media formats.

1084176177504440322.text: Video games: Currency of a developing country with a fast-growing economy that is still mostly overlooked by major world powers. Visitors realize everything they buy is cheap after determining its conversion to dollars, due in part to an absence of local labor laws & regulations.

1084173282113392641.text: 3D prints: often used as fake toy money for children.

1084172760346173441.text: Writing: Appears to be of greater value relative to other currencies than it will actually turn out to be after accounting for the difficulties involved in conversion.

1084171034515984387.text: Art: would operate similarly to the price of oil; inherently valuable as a physical object, but price can abruptly vary due to external factors.

1084170491152216064.text:
If media formats were currencies:

Movies: stable but slow-growing, physically backed by licensed toys.

Music: weak after inflation, sometimes used as wallpaper.

Social media posting: rampant speculation.

Buildings: like gold, direct relation btwn physical content & value.

1082692504934326274.text: Something else to mention is the jarring disconnect btwn impression you get of an author referenced in paper books, & what happens when you receive more recent information by typing that name into Google. 1082687271592169474.text: (Though the latter situation can also be a source of this problem, probably depending on which field you are in/what argument you're trying to make. 1082685869763579904.text: The two situations where this came up for me both involved people suspected of plagiarism after they became influential, which makes it a more literal obstacle to writing credible arguments than it would be if you just needed to cite someone who had a problematic personal life.

1082684813486817282.text: It's hard when too many sources point to a "great man" (broadly speaking) whom you can no longer feel comfortable referencing, because the past prominence of the discredited source means that fewer alternatives were developed.

1082684589561257984.text: ex. if someone is suspected of copying another more marginalized person's ideas, we somehow need to create a way to update older chains of knowledge to guide people creating new references.

1082684058633715712.text: A new kind of contemporary academic challenge is the situation where you need to find alternative sources to replace a lineage of interlinked discourses based on the theories of a particular author who has now been discredited.
